question: Drug of choice for Prophylaxis against Diphtheria is
exp: Control of Diphtheria Prophylaxis of Diphtheria Erythromycin Non-immunized contacts Prophylactic Penicillin/Erythromycin + 1000-2000 units antitoxin + active immunization DOC for carriers Erythromycin DOC for cases Penicillin/Erythromycin (given along with anti-toxin)

question: Most common site of Hydatid cyst in human body is:-
exp: Hydatid disease: Caused by infection with a small tapeworm parasite called Echinococcus granulosus. Most common site of hydatid cyst in human body is Right postero-superior lobe of liver. In hydatid disease, 70% of cysts are located in right lobe of liver. Rest are located in lungs, brain, peritoneum, long bones and kidney.

question: A mother brought her 10-month-old baby to PHC centre with complaints of loose watery stools and vomiting from 1 day. On examination child was dehydrated and had fever. Which of the following can be the most common cause of child's condition?
exp: Rotavirus- MC and leading cause of watery diarrhea in children aged <5 years globally. In developing countries, 3/4th of children acquire their first episode of rotavirus diarrhea before the age of 12 months. Severe rotavirus gastroenteritis is largely limited to children aged 6-24 months. Transmit by feco-oral route / indirectly by contaminated fomites. Causes diarrhea & vomiting leading to dehydration. Other options: E. coli can cause travellers' diarrhea. It is also most common bacterial cause of UTIs Shigella causes bloody diarrhea. Malnutrition causes persistent diarrhea - which lasts 14 days or longer.

question: A 10 yr old boy complains of acute bloody diarrhea along with history of fever. The doctor on duty suspects it to be due to Shigella infection. what would be the Drug of choice for it?
exp: History of fever along with acute bloody diarrhoea indicates Shigella infection. DOC for Shigella infection is Ciprofloxacin. Symptoms of Shigella Symptoms Shigella Diarrhoea Acute bloody Fever Yes Abdominal cramps Yes Vomiting No Rectal pain Yes Stool > 3 stools/day, with blood or pus.

question: Under AFP Surveillance, follow-up examination is done after (For residual paralysis)
exp: Under AFP Surveillance, follow-up examination is done after (For residual paralysis) 60 days of onset of paralysis - Acute flacid paralysis is seen polio myelitis AFP surveillance done at 0-15 yrs. Age group in India done by surveillance medical officer 2 stood specimen collect to suspected person 24 - 48 hr. apa Each simple. 8 gm ( adult thumb size) - Transpoed in reverse cold chain ( +2 to + 8degC) Follow up after 60 days Confirmation of polio by 90 days

question: Why is Sugar added in ORS?
exp: Adding sugar to ORS, enhances absorption of salt & water. Sugar in the ORS has found to have sym- transpoer mechanism with sodium. Composition Weight Osmolar concentration (mmol/litre) Sodium chloride 2. 6 gm Sodium 75 Potassium chloride 1. 5 gm Potassium 20 Sodium citrate 2. 9 gm Chloride 65 Glucose, anhydrous 13. 5 gm Citrate 10 Glucose, anhydrous 75 Total 20. 5 gms Total 245 EXTRA-EDGE: Re. So. MAL: Rehydration solution for MALnourished Sodium - halved to 45 mmol/L; Potassium - Doubled to 40 mmol /L SUPER ORS: Rice /starch/ Alanine based

question: Peri-natal transmission of hepatitis B is maximum in:
exp: Peri-natal transmission of hepatitis B is maximum in 3rd trimester. Maximum chances of perinatal transmission:- Disease Maximum chances Varicella 1 trimester Rubella 1 trimester Syphilis III trimester Toxoplasmosis III trimester Hepatitis B III trimester HIV During delivery

question: Marker of Infectivity of Hepatitis B is:-
exp: HBs. Ag first antigen to appear, epidemio marker ( Australian antigen ) HBc. Ag - Rarely appears in plasma HBe. Ag - Marker of infectivity 1st Ab to appearance - Anti HBC Ab - acute hepatitis IgM Anti HBe - Marker of good prognosis Anti HBs - End of communicability and vaccinated.

question: Which of the following hepatitis is associated with higher moality in pregnancy?
exp: HEPATITIS-E: Calcivirus HEV in pregnancy: fulminant form of hepatitis E infection is seen during pregnancy with high case fatality rate HEV is essentially a waterborne disease; Feco-oral route of transmission Incubation period: 21-45 days Also Remember, Hepatitis type Type Incubation period Route of transmission A Entero-virus 72 15-45 Days Feco-oral route - MC in children in India B Hepa. DNA virus 45-180 Days Blood, sexual, parenteral C Hepaci virus 30-120 days Blood, sexual, parenteral D Viroids like 30-90 days Blood, sexual, parenteral

question: Serological pattern observed for Acute Hepatitis B, with active viral replication is:
exp: Hepatitis B virus expresses three antigens, viz. Corresponding antibodies produced on stimulation of immune system are: 1. HBs. Ag (Australia antigen) - surface antigen - 1st antigen to appear 2. HBc. Ag - core antigen - Rarely appears alone 3. HBe. Ag - Marker of infectivity, indicate active viral replication 1. Anti-HBs - Marker of end of period of communicability 2. Anti-HBc - 1st Ab to appear 3. Anti-HBe - Marker of good prognosis Serological patterns seen in Hepatitis B infection are: Condition Serological Pattern Acute Hepatitis B HBs. Ag, HBe. Ag, IgM Anti-HBc Chronic Hepatitis B, with active viral replication Hbs. Ag, HBe. Ag, IgG Anti-HBc Chronic Hepatitis B, with low viral replication Hbs. Ag, IgG Anti-HBc, Anti-HBe Recovery from Hepatitis B infection Anti-HBs, IgG Anti-HBc Post Vaccination Anti-HBs
opa: HBs. Ag, HBe. Ag, IgM Anti-HBc

question: Which of the following disease has incubation period< 1week?
exp: Incubation period of cholera: 1-2 days. Incubation period of kala azar: 1-4 months. Incubation period of filariasis: 8-16 months. Incubation period of measles: 10-14 days.
